doc.field: Fifty-three killed in plane crash

Fifty-three people were killed today when a Boeing 727 of the Ecuadorian carrier Tame crashed into a mountain 3 minutes after the start. Three Germans are among the dead. The plane was on its way from Bogota, Columbia to the Ecuadorian capital Quito.
Committees recommend introduction of Euro currency

The parliamentary committees for finances, foreign affairs and Europe recommended that the parliament approves the introduction of the Euro currency on 1 January 1999. Thus, a wide acceptance of the common currency in the two houses of parliament, Bundestag and Bundesrat, seems guaranteed. In a joint hearing Chancellor Helmut Kohl had promoted again the Euro and stressed that the monetary union would also advance the political union in Europe. Kohl said the monetary union is the most important decision since the re-unification of the two German states. The conditions for the stability of the new currency have never been as good as today. In the Bundesrat even Euro-sceptics seem to turn around. The state premiers of Lower-Saxony, Bavaria, and Baden-Wuerttemberg said they would vote in favour. Saxony is going to vote against the common currency. The Bundestag will decide on Thursday, the Bundesrat on Friday about the introduction of the Euro.
German-French argument about stability declaration

The argument between Germany and France about the Euro stability declaration suggested by German Finance Minister Theo Waigel continues. Waigel had demanded that a budget surplus must be used to reduce the debt. French Finance Minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn, however, reiterated that a surplus could also be used to finance programmes to create jobs.
Pungent criticism of FDP congress resolution to abolish solidarity tax

The state premiers of East Germany have criticized strongly the FDP congress' resolution to abolish the solidarity tax completely. [The tax was introduced to help East Germany after the re-unification.]. Thuringia's State Premier Vogel said he who wants to abolish the solidarity tax gives the impression that the time of solidarity was over. Saxony-Anhalt's State Premier Reinhard Hoeppner accused the FDP of having discarded the East. The State Premier of Mecklenburg-East Pomerania Bernhardt Seite said the subsidy of the new states must not be touched. The FDP, however, stated that there was no disagreement in the government coalition about the demand to reduce taxes drastically and to abolish the solidarity tax completely. FDP faction leader Dorothee Solms stated that each party has the right to independently adopt its own election platform for the following legislative period. This was not a breach of the coalition contract. Therefore, this topic was not raised at the coalition meeting this morning.
Gysi continues to claim his innocence

In a hearing by the parliamentary immunity committee PDS politician Gregor Gysi has stated again that he has never worked for the Stasi [the former East German domestic intelligence service]. He accused the committee of trying to discredit him morally and politically. The committee had found in March that there was unequivocal evidence that Gysi had worked as an Unofficial Collaborator for the Stasi. Gysi has tried in vain to have the report halted by the Federal Constitutional Court.
RAF letter genuine: discussions about consequences

The voluntary disbandment of the terrorist "Red Army Fraction" (RAF) has started up a broad discussion of the possible legal consequences. Union politicians and constitution protectors have warned against a premature lifting or relaxing of the anti-terrorist legislation brought into place in the 1970s. Buendnis 90/The Greens argued however, that the legislation should be annulled following the disbandment of the RAF. The acting chairman of the SPD parliamentary fraction Schily and the FDP politician Leutheusser-Schnarrenberger called for a relaxation of rules on criminal prosecution. The Federal Crime Office reckons that the letter published yesterday announcing the disbandment of the terrorist group as genuine. The criminological examination showed that the RAF star on the letter corresponded exactly with the symbol used in previous letters. The water mark on the letter was also identical to that of previous letters.
No agreement after first round of chemical industry wage negotiations

The first round of the central wage negotiations for the 590,000 employees of the west German chemical industry in Bad Wildungen, Hessen, had not achieved a break-through by yesterday evening. The Mining, Chemicals and Energy Union is demanding wage increases of between 5 and 5.5 percent as well as the creation of additional apprenticeship places.
German exports booming

The German export economy continues to boom. Firms exported goods to a value of DM66 billion abroad, according to the Federal Statistics Office. This represents an increase of 13.4 percent against February 1997. Imports grew by nearly 10 percent to around DM65 billion. This means a balance of trade excess of almost DM12 billion, almost DM3 billion more than in February 1997.
New record level of company bankruptcies

Company bankruptcies in Germany look likely to reach a new record this year. The Hermes Credit Insurance Co. announced in Hamburg that the number of insolvencies in 1998 will rise for the fifth successive year by a further two percent to 28,000 cases. In 1997 the number of collapses, at 27,500, represented an increase of eight percent on the previous record. In 1991 there were only 9,000 insolvencies.
Letters reaching destinations quicker

The length of time it takes for domestic mail to reach its destination has decreased further. Some 94 out of 100 items are arriving within one day, the Post HQ in Bonn announced. 99 percent of all letters arrive at least within two days. Four years ago the results were only 83 percent arrival in one day. The mail service puts the improvement down to the establishment of around 60 mail centres. These centres can, depending on their capacity, deal with up to 4.5 million items each day.
Mammoth coverage by ARD and ZDF of soccer world cup

ARD and ZDF will produce around 225 hours of television coverage of the football World Cup in France, which will take place between 10 June and 12 July. This was announced by the team boss of ARD and ZDF, the WDR director Pleitgen in Cologne this evening. 56 of the 64 games will be broadcast live. Around 320 TV personnel will work on seamless reporting on radio and TV from the 10 stadia being used in the competition. Pleitgen emphasised that the coverage of the 16th World Cup will be the largest broadcasting excercise in the history of ARD and ZDF.
Schaven presents reform plan for Baden-Wuerttemberg leaving certificate

The Baden-Wuerttemberg Culture Minister Schaven has presented the details of her controversial reform plan for the school leaving certificate (Abitur). In future the division between minor and major exam subjects will be abolished. Instead, German, math, and one foreign language will be compulsory exam subjects and taught four lessons [one lesson equals 45 minutes] per week. One additional "profile" subject must be chosen and will also be taught four lessons per week. All other subjects will be taught 2 lessons per week. The Abitur exam will comprise four written and one oral examination. According to Schaven the system will be introduced in 2001.
